Expectation1: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation1: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I massaged shampoo into my client’s hair, feeling the thick, sticky buildup resisting my fingers. She needed a deep cleanse and careful detangling before I could even think about cutting, but the process would take at least another hour. My heart thudded with anxiety. Today was the day of my cousin’s wedding ceremony, and as a Hindu, my presence was not just expected—it was essential. I was supposed to arrive early, dressed in my best sari, to help with the rituals and greet the elders. My mother had called twice already, reminding me not to be late. But here I was, hands deep in suds, knowing I couldn’t rush this client without compromising my work. The salon’s expectations pressed on me: every client deserves my full attention and skill. Yet, the weight of my family’s traditions and the importance of the ceremony pulled me in the opposite direction. I could feel the tension building inside me, torn between my professional pride and my cultural duty, unsure which demand I could afford to disappoint.
